Body.copy:
After 100 days of sound and fury in Washington DC, words such as unprecedented and normal have been drained of meaning.
But one thing has remained constant during the Donald Trump presidency: having lost the [popular vote](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2016/nov/08/us-election-2016-results-live-clinton-trump) but won the electoral college, he took office with the lowest approval rating of any incoming president; he now has the lowest [approval rating](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/23/100-days-how-trump-compares-to-last-five-presidents) of any president at the 100-day mark, although polls suggest his base remains loyal. "He's learning on the job, which is dangerous," says Rich Galen, a Republican strategist, "but at least he's learning".

The most notable and durable achievement is Trumpâ€™s appointment of [Neil Gorsuch](https://www.theguardian.com/law/2017/apr/07/senate-confirms-neil-gorsuch-supreme-court-trump) to the supreme court despite concerted opposition from Democrats which forced Republicans to change Senate rules. His selection was welcomed by conservatives craving a worthy successor to [Antonin Scalia](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/feb/13/antonin-scalia-dead-us-supreme-court-justice-obituary), who died 14 months ago. 

Trump has also signed a record 13 resolutions to roll back regulations, billed by the White House as "getting government out of the way" to create jobs, and pulled out of the [Trade Pacific Partnership](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/23/donald-trump-first-orders-trans-pacific-partnership-tpp) trade deal. He was hailed by some for moving swiftly to punish Syria for using chemical weapons.

But to many observers, the list of failures is far longer. Trumpâ€™s rushed attempt to [repeal and replace](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/25/donald-trump-healthcare-deal-republicans-obamacare) Obamaâ€™s signature healthcare legislation, which crashed in the House of Representatives, was â€œa debacleâ€ . Trump, who has sold himself as the ultimate deal maker, could not strike the deal and reports suggested that he had little grasp of the details.

And soon after taking office, Trump signed an [executive order](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/16/trump-new-travel-ban-blocked-explainer-what-next) to ban visitors from seven Muslim-majority countries; the result was an outcry over a betrayal of America's values, pandemonium at airports and defeat in the courts. A revised ban met the same fate. It was an early victory for Americaâ€™s system of checks and balances that prompted Trump to vent his frustration.

It became clear very quickly that President Trump would be the same as candidate Trump. In his inaugural address, he spoke of [â€œAmerican carnageâ€](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jan/20/donald-trump-inauguration-speech-analysis) and set out a flinty nationalist agenda. 

One day later, Trumpâ€™s press secretary Sean Spicer angrily berated the media over its reporting on the size of his [inaugural crowd](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/22/trump-inauguration-crowd-sean-spicers-claims-versus-the-evidence), falsely claiming that Trumpâ€™s had been bigger than Obamaâ€™s, setting the tone for 100 days of belligerence and combative relations with the press.

The president is still holding campaign rallies and still reflecting on the election as if happiest when heâ€™s fighting. Sexism and racism have been less explicit than during the election campaign but there have been peculiar incidents such as a failure to shake German chancellor [Angela Merkelâ€™s hand](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/video/2017/mar/17/donald-trump-angela-merkel-no-handshake-video) and the blunt language of â€œradical Islamic terrorismâ€ .

Since becoming president, Trump has put out nearly a thousand tweets. Some are impulsively fired off at all hours of the night - often in response to items broadcast on Fox News. A tone more different from Obama is harder to imagine.

At his first speech to a joint session of Congress, Trump promised a â€œnew chapter in American greatnessâ€ . He spoke of healthcare reform, a tax overhaul, a trillion dollar infrastructure package and the breath of life for dying industries to create millions of new jobs. There was also his plan for a wall on the Mexican border, of which there is no sign of construction yet.

But while Trump has signed more executive orders than any of his 12 predecessors, he has no major legislation to his name and has failed to break the Washington gridlock.

After spending seven years fighting Obamacare, the party could not get its act together to find a replacement that they all agreed on. Similar divisions could plague sweeping [tax reform](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/26/trump-tax-cuts-proposal-deductions-brackets) announced on Wednesday while the infrastructure package is likely to need support from Democrats, something they have no incentive under pressure from grassroots activists.

His failure to earn trust, for example because of his tweets accusing [Obama of wiretapping](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/15/wiretap-trump-house-intelligence-committee), have â€œaffected the ability of the president to get legislation achievements, which is crucial,â€ says Leon Panetta, former defence secretary and CIA director. â€œYou cannot be a president and govern by executive orders. The fact heâ€™s been issuing them all has been more politicking than effective policy and some has run into checks and balances.â€

Trump claimed at a [freewheeling press conference](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/16/alexander-acosta-labor-secretary-nomination-donald-trump) that his administration is â€˜running like a fine-tuned machineâ€. But he is the first president in US history to have no public sector experience and, some would say, it shows in instances small and big.

There have been press releases with spelling mistakes and press briefings by Spicer littered with mispronunciations and worse; he was forced to apologise for claiming that [Adolf Hitler](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/11/sean-spicer-hitler-chemical-weapons-holocaust-assad) did not use chemical weapons against his own people. 

The travel ban was widely criticised as rushed with a chronic lack of basic consultation and fact checking, for example on the status of green card holders from the affected countries. It ran into the buzzsaw of the courts. The health care bill fared no better with the Congressional Budget Office warning that it would result in [24 million](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/13/budget-office-republican-healthcare-coverage-deficit-costs) more uninsured Americans by 2026. â€œNobody knew healthcare could be so complicated,â€ Trump confessed.

Trump has spent around three quarters of his presidency at the White House. On numerous weekends he has gone to Mar-a-Lago, his â€œwinter White Houseâ€ in Palm Beach, Florida. He is regularly on the golf course despite criticising Obama for playing.

Benjamin Wittes, senior fellow in governance studies at the Brookings Institution in Washington, told an audience at the think tank this week: â€œIn the bilateral battle between malevolence and incompetence, incompetence is certainly winning.â€

The election of Trump last November was a shot heard around the world. Rarely had there been such uncertainty in foreign capitals yet the worst prophecies of doom have not come to pass. 

So far it seems the Trump doctrine is that there is no doctrine, but rather a pragmatic response to circumstances on a case by case basis. The â€œAmerica firstâ€  isolationism that fired up his supporters was jettisoned when the president saw primetime images of children and â€œbeautiful babiesâ€ gassed in Syria. [Trump ordered](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/apr/06/trump-syria-missiles-assad-chemical-weapons) a strike by 59 Tomahawk missiles on a Syrian airfield in response.

The intervention was praised by Republican hawks as decisive leadership but he president spoiled the effect somewhat in a TV interview in which he [recalled](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/12/trump-xi-jinping-chocolate-cake-syria-strikes) ordering the attack over â€œthe most beautiful piece of chocolate cake that you have ever seenâ€ .

Aggressive postures have also been taken towards North Korea and Iran. Authoritarian figures in Egypt and Turkey have been embraced. There have also been head-snapping reversals, with Russia falling out of favour and China falling into favour and, as for Nato: â€œI said it was obsolete. Itâ€™s no longer obsolete.â€ 

Panetta says: â€œI think the world has drawn some degree of comfort by virtue of the national security team but there are still mixed messages going out as to whether there is any underlying strategy to the steps heâ€™s taking on Syria and North Korea.â€

US intelligence agencies [concluded](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/dec/10/cia-concludes-russia-interfered-to-help-trump-win-election-report) that Moscow-backed hackers meddled in the presidential election to tip the scales against Hillary Clinton and in favour of Trump. But the burning question is whether Trumpâ€™s campaign actively colluded with a foreign adversary - a potential scandal bigger than Watergate.

There has been a drip-drip of revelations and investigations launched by the House, Senate and FBI. It is not yet known if their witnesses will include Christopher Steele, a former British intelligence operative who compiled a [dossier](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/11/trump-russia-dossier-explainer-details) containing salacious allegations linking Trump to Moscow.

[Mike Flynn](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/13/michael-flynn-resigns-quits-trump-national-security-adviser-russia) became the first major casualty of the administration when he was forced to resign for misleading Vice-President Mike Pence over his conversations with Russian ambassador Sergey Kislyak. Attorney general Jeff Sessions also faced calls to quit and conceded: â€œI should have slowed down and said, â€˜But I did meet one Russian official a couple of times.â€™â€ 

According to recent reports, federal investigators have gathered intelligence that suggests Russian operatives may have used Carter Page, a former Merrill Lynch banker whom Trump referred to as a foreign policy adviser during the presidential race, to gain access to the candidate. Page, who has â€œpro-Kremlinâ€  views, has denied sharing any information of consequence.

The internecine warfare, intrguing plot twists and rise and fall of various [protagonists](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/04/trump-inner-circle-white-house-court) has made Game of Thrones look positively modest. For a while it seemed that chief strategist Steve Bannon, anti-globalist advocate for dismantling the administrative state, was all powerful, but then the former head of Breitbart News apparently flew too close to the sun.Trump is said to have been irritated by what he saw as Bannonâ€™s self-aggrandising appearance on a Time magazine cover with the label, â€œThe Great Manipulatorâ€ ,

Instead it is now a New York faction that holds sway: Ivanka has a formal position and her husband Jared Kushner has an outsized portfolio, while Goldman Sachs veterans Gary Cohn, chief economic adviser, and Steven Mnuchin, treasury secretary, increasingly have the presidentâ€™s ear. The inner circle also includes Vice-President Mike Pence, Chief of Staff Reince Preibus, policy adviser [Stephen Miller](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/mar/15/stephen-miller-new-trump-travel-ban) and senior adviser [Kellyanne Conway](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/10/kellyanne-conway-white-house-gaffes-three-strikes-but-not-yet-out), whose gaffes have included a reference to â€œalternative factsâ€ .

Secretary of state Rex Tillerson made a slow start, but sprang into life at the time of the Syria strike with harsh words for Russia. Trumpâ€™s national security team has drawn particular praise: after Flynnâ€™s departure, he chose the widely respected H R McMaster as national security adviser, a move that led to Bannonâ€™s departure from the national security council. Defense Secretary Jim Mattis is also a relatively conventional choice.

But other appointments have set alarm bells ringing. Sessions is an anti-immigration hardliner who has faced allegations of racism. [Scott Pruitt](https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/feb/17/scott-pruitt-confirmed-epa-emails-senate), head of the Environmental Protection Agency, is a climate change sceptic who previously sued the agency 14 times.

For a president to own an international business empire on such a scale is unprecedented. At a press conference on 11 January, Trump said he would remove himself from the day-to-day operation of his eponymous organisation and put his holdings in a revocable trust managed by his two adult sons, Eric and Donald Jr.

But while this removes him from day-to-day decision making, [ProPublica reported](https://www.propublica.org/article/trump-pull-money-his-businesses-whenever-he-wants-without-telling-us) that Trump could draw money from the trust at any time without external disclosure. 

The Trump International Hotel, a few blocks from the White House, is popular with diplomats, raising the prospect that foreign governments could see booking expensive rooms there as a way to gain favour with the president.

And on the day that Ivanka Trump dined with Chinese president Xi at Mar-a-Lago, the Chinese government approved three [new trademarks](https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/apr/19/ivanka-trump-brand-china-trademarks-day-us-president-met-xi-jinping) for her company to sell items in China. White House senior adviser Kellyanne Conway was reprimanded after urging TV viewers to buy Ivankaâ€™s products.

The White House insists that Trump has made â€œsacrificesâ€ and is not taking a salary, donating the first chunk to national parks. But the president continues to break with four decades of tradition by refusing to release his tax returns.

All the evidence of the past 100 days suggests that the future is profoundly unpredictable. A second stab at healthcare reform could be imminent. The North Korea crisis is brewing. There are some clues that the early disarray in the White House may be gradually stabilising. But Trump is still Trump and that presents the world with a strange and sometimes frightening enigma. Panetta asks: "Is he the tweeting Trump who's the TV personality or the businessman Trump who can be more responsible in terms of getting things done? The American people are still trying to figure out who is the real president of the United States."

GreatestAchievements.title: Regulation reform
GreatestAchievements.description: Business liked moves including forcing federal agencies to cut two regulations for every new one

GreatestAchievements.title: Foreign policy changes
GreatestAchievements.description: Trump's strikes against Syria and tough talk on North Korea did at least signal a new approach

GreatestAchievements.title: Supreme Court judge
GreatestAchievements.description: Trump got his pick for the vacant Supreme Court seat, Neil Gorsuch, after a row over rule changes

GreatestAchievements.title: Easter egg roll
GreatestAchievements.description: The 139th White House Easter egg roll passed off without major incident

WorstFailures.title: Muslim ban
WorstFailures.description: The executive order to ban visitors to the US from seven Muslim-majority countries prompted outcry and was defeated in the courts

WorstFailures.title: Wiretap claim
WorstFailures.description: In early morning tweets Trump accused President Obama of having him wiretapped, citing no evidence

WorstFailures.title: Healthcare debacle
WorstFailures.description: The promise to repeal and replace crashed in the Senate

TheRussiaQuestion.title: Mike Flynn resigns
TheRussiaQuestion.description: Trump's national security adviser quits over misleading accounts of chats with the Russian ambassador

TheRussiaQuestion.title: Jeff Sessions
TheRussiaQuestion.description: The attorney general has to recuse himself from the Russian investigations after making misleading statements over his contacts

TheRussiaQuestion.title: FBI investigation
TheRussiaQuestion.description: James Comey, FBI boss, publicly announces it is investigating possible Trump campaign coordination with Russia

TheRussiaQuestion.title: Devin Nunes escapades
TheRussiaQuestion.description: The chair of the House Intelligence Committee gets embroiled in a row about briefings at the White House over the affair

TheRussiaQuestion.title: Carter Page
TheRussiaQuestion.description: The former adviser to Trump was "strongly-pro Kremlin", a former employer tells the Guardian

TeamTrump.title: Steve Bannon
TeamTrump.description: The chief strategist's star waned after headlines said he was pulling all the strings

TeamTrump.title: Gary Cohn
TeamTrump.description: The Goldman Sachs veteran becomes more influential over the 100 days in his role as chief economic adviser

TeamTrump.title: Ivanka Trump
TeamTrump.description: The first daughter makes her role in the White House official and is a powerful duo alongside husband Jared Kushner, a top aide

TeamTrump.title: Jared Kushner
TeamTrump.description: Ivanka's husband gets an ever expanding list of responsibilities including solving the Middle East peace process and the opioids epidemic

TeamTrump.title: Sean Spicer
TeamTrump.description: The White House press secretary becomes compulsive viewing trying to spin the administration and survives a terrible gaffe over comments about Hitler
